Mature tools are available to perform NER (GATE, NLTK, Stanford NER, etc.), but not for entity extraction . for sentiment analysis, an additional step is usually needed to group the entities into synonyms
in traditional NER, the objective is to recognize all named entities of certain types in a corpus . in sentiment mining, the interest is often to find the mentions of a set of desired entities, e.g.
the task is to cluster entity mentions, and map them to target entities . page 14 Entity resolution .
entity information can be obtained from meta-data . domain-focused corpora focusing on discussions of a specific type of products or topics . need to perform entity extraction and linking .
keyword search is often applied first to retrieve relevant posts . due to polysemy, a filtering step may be required to get posts that truly contain the desired entities .
page 17 Another complexity . in sentiment analysis applications involving consumer products, the entities are products, which typically have brands and models forming a hierarchical relationship .
instead of PER(person), ORG(organization), GPE(geopolitical entity), UNK(unknown), we are typically looking for products, services, and brands .

supervised entity extraction using HMM or CRF is still applicable . but it requires labeling of training data, which may not always be possible . semi-supervised approaches try to tap on unlabeled examples .
use a PU learning algorithm like S-EM (Liu et al., 2002) to learn a classification model to label the candidates .
NER task is trivial when the ID and date/time of the post are usually known . for other data, like news articles, they may need to be extracted out of text .
